project.teaser: Despite improved understanding of the need for science to inform biodiversity related policy making and the rich field of science-policy interfaces (SPIs) there remains a gap in ensuring that all decision makers across all societal sectors have direct access to research-based...
project.objective: Despite improved understanding of the need for science to inform biodiversity related policy making and the rich field of science-policy interfaces (SPIs) there remains a gap in ensuring that all decision makers across all societal sectors have direct access to research-based knowledge when planning, budgeting and deciding on actions that have an impact on local, national, EU and global biodiversity. BioAgora will develop a Science Service for Biodiversity (hereafter referred to as Science Service), which responds to the present gaps and future needs in SPIs and provides the science pillar of the EU’s Knowledge Centre for Biodiversity (KCBD). It will channel the entire landscape of EU biodiversity science from monitoring to meta-analyses and communicate this knowledge through two-way platforms to EU institutions and the broader community. To do this, the project will use ongoing processes of SPIs across Europe and beyond, as knowledge exchange networks, to address the most urgent needs identified for the Science Service. BioAgora will go beyond the state of the art by co-creating new ways of bridging the gap between science, practice and policy and use this as a basis for the Science Service’s development for future needs. To do this, it will 1) analyse the existing landscape of SPIs, assess their policy tools and the current biodiversity knowledge held in Europe, 2) engage with a broad range of actors –those already established ones and those not yet fully integrated within the landscape, as well as the users of SPIs; 3) form the Science Service governance structure and systems model along the projects span by testing it in real life; 4) provide capacity building for the EU community of decision makers to become empowered for transformative change for biodiversity. BioAgora will deliver a functional and responsive Science Service, capable of providing a one-stop-shop for fit-for-purpose materials and tools which enable decision makers to secure biodiversity and sustainability transformation.
project.title: Bio Knowledge Agora: Developing the Science Service for European Research and Biodiversity Policymaking

article.title: Bridging the gap between science, practice and policy

result.title: Report on transformative potential of the SPI networks
result.description: This deliverable is linked with Task 2.3. The report will summarise the results of the assessment of the transformative change of SPIs and SPSIs, including criteria for pluralizing work and incorporating multiple values of nature, engaging with power relations in ways that unlock barriers, building social relations and agency for collective action, and ways of embedding insights and outputs into every day decision making across individual and collective levels.

result.title: Initial Plan for Dissemination, Exploitation and Communication of Results of BioAgora (PDEC)
result.description: The PDEC will propose all dissemination, exploitation and communication activities in BioAgora guaranteeing its impact. Includes impact assessment and KPIs.

result.title: Report on Policy Network Analysis results including a map of actors and SPI networks
result.description: This deliverable is linked with Task 2.1. This report will present the results of the PNA, including the map where all the key actors and already existing SPI networds are presented. The report will show cross-scale dimensions of actors from local to global, as well as with whom they are interlinked and connected. Relationships of interest may be about information and resource exchange between actors, or who are considered influential/powerful actors by others. In addition, the report includes the different roles of actors within networks, e.g. gatekeepers are in a strategic position as they form the bridge between otherwise disconnected actor.

result.title: Typology of challenges as input to Tasks 1.2 and 1.3
result.description: This deliverable is linked with Task 1.1. This deliverable will build on the analysis of the EU Biodiversity Strategy to 2030, carried out in T1.1, to identify key challenges that can limit the achievement of the strategic goals and to create a typology of challenges which will be used in the demonstration cases in T1.2 and T1.3 to generate opportunities on how to overcome the barriers.

result.title: Mapping the needs of decision-makers to tailor capacity development activities
result.description: This deliverable is linked with Task 5.1. This deliverable summarizes the results of the needs assessment carried out in T5.1 through in-depth interviews with relevant actors of current SP(S)I activities. The analysis will also consult data collected in T2.1, T3.1 and T4.1 on gaps and challenges. Based on the needs assessment, the deliverable will identify capacity development priorities to be taken up in T5.2.

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
